text: can I call deleted the opposition right
from Jericho
Thank You mr. speaker can I join me can
I join the Prime Minister in remembering
the horror of what happened on London
Bridge less than three weeks ago it's
the third time in the last two general
election campaigns we've witnessed these
appalling and depraved terrorist attacks
on our communities and our families our
hearts must go out to the families of
Saskia Jones and Jack Merritt and when
the Prime Minister and I attended a
memorial event at the Guildhall we had
the honor of meeting I had the honor of
meeting many of the students that have
been at college with with Jack and they
were just devastated and in his memory
they wanted his work and his message to
carry on and I think we should remember
the very good words of his father David
about how proud he was of his son on
that day that attack was an attempt to
damage our democracy to halt the process
it didn't succeed and it never should
succeed because we have to make sure
that our democracy is fully intact Mr
Speaker I would like to offer my
congratulations the Prime Minister on
winning the election and being returned
to office and I want to pay tribute to
those members from my party particularly
who sadly lost their seats in the
election and therefore will not be here
in particular although many would
remember but obviously Denis Skinner is
somebody that comes very much to mind on
this occasion and the Prime Minister in
the campaign made many many promises and
therefore has tremendous
responsibilities to live up to he'll be
judged on whether he keeps those
promises are not by the communities that
he's made them to our job in the labour
party will be hold this government to
account and stand up to the communities
that we represent and for the more than
10 million people that voted for our
party in the general election because
that is what parliamentary democracy is
about holding government to account and
representing the people that have sent
us here on their behalf can I also mr.
speaker elect offer my congratulations
the Honourable member for Worthing West
on
his position of father of the house I
first encountered him in the Bullock's
West by-election in 1975 I was a trade
union organizer at the time and I made a
very strong recommendation to all of my
members of the Union that they should
vote for the Labour candidate and not
him
and some of them went to see him and
came back and I'd really quite
embarrassing they said he seemed such a
very nice man we might well vote for him
I said I don't want to further tarnish
his reputation by saying that some years
ago whenever I was trying to get an
all-party consensus together on an early
day motion sometimes a difficult task he
would often give it a conservative
character by supporting such such moves
I want to thank him for that
and wish him well as father of the house
can I take this opportunity to welcome
all newly elected members to the house
it is a very daunting day for them first
day to be elected here on behalf of your
constituents and all the responsibility
that goes with it there is no greater
honor than to be elected to this house
to represent your constituents and one
of the greatest strengths of our
political system is that every one of us
represents a community every one of us
has a constituency we're there to
represent the homeless and the desperate
as well as those that are better off and
lead more comfortable existences we are
there to represent all of them and that
surely ought to be the watchword of our
house and our democracy this is the
first time a majority of Labour MPs are
women and I congratulate all of them
that's been elected and 20 of the 26
newly elected Labour MPs are women
something that compares rather favorably
to the performance of the Conservative
Party in this election
this is also mr. speaker mr. speaker
elect the most diverse Parliament in
history and I'm proud that 41 of the 65
black of minority ethnic MPs are on the
Labour benches and I know they will do a
fantastic job representing their
constituencies and wider community
interests and finally Mr Speaker I want
to offer my warmest congratulations to
you as you resume your place in the
speaker's chair it's great to see you
back your role goes beyond the pomp and
the ceremony and that's something you
very well understand and you I'm keen to
work with you as many others are on all
the other issues facing this house this
house can't function without members
staff house staff security
administration caterers cleaners and
officials that do so much good work here
they all make a contribution to ensure
our democracy functions properly but
there's also enormous pressure on em
pays on staff and many others and I know
that you take very seriously the mental
health and well-being of all of us and I
hope in this house we will ensure that
that is the case because complete
conclude mr. speaker with this in your
house there are portraits of many of
your predecessors indeed all of your
predecessors have portraits all around
there and one of the most famous is of
course speaker lentil who resisted the
autocracy of Charles the first in
support of the freedoms of parliament
our democracy needs you mr. speaker as a
speaker who will stand firm against
abuses of power by the executive or by
anybody else in doing so you're not just
defending the rights of this house but
the rights of millions of people who put
their faith in a democratic system to
elect a parliament and therefore a
government that is answerable to them
our rights and freedoms are always
precious but also often precarious
democracy is not a given it's something
we have to extend and defend and I'm
sure you in your role as speaker elect
and hopefully speaker very soon will do
exactly that I congratulate you on your
election look forward to working with
you
so
